title: Why Real Estate is a Great Investment: The Power of Property
excerpt: When it comes to building wealth, real estate stands out as one of the most reliable and rewarding investment options. Whether you're a seasoned investor or just starting to explore your options, property offers a unique blend of benefits that few other assets can match.
content:
When it comes to building wealth, real estate stands out as one of the most reliable and rewarding investment options. Whether you're a seasoned investor or just starting to explore your options, property offers a unique blend of benefits that few other assets can match. Here’s why real estate is such a great investment: 

#### 1. Tangible Asset

Unlike stocks or cryptocurrency, real estate is a physical asset. You can see it, touch it, and use it, whether it’s a residential property you rent out or commercial space you develop. This tangible nature gives many investors peace of mind, knowing their wealth is tied to something real and not just numbers on a screen.

#### 2. Appreciation Over Time

Historically, real estate has appreciated in value, often outpacing inflation and other asset classes. While the market can experience short-term fluctuations, properties in prime locations tend to grow in value over the long haul. If you buy smart and hold on for the ride, the returns can be significant.

#### 3. Steady Cash Flow

One of the most attractive features of real estate is the potential for consistent passive income. If you invest in rental properties, you can receive a steady stream of cash flow each month from tenants. This regular income can cover expenses and generate profits, creating financial stability and freedom.

#### 4. Tax Benefits

Real estate investors benefit from a range of tax breaks, including deductions for mortgage interest, property taxes, and depreciation. These perks can significantly reduce your taxable income and increase your overall returns, making real estate not just an investment, but a smart financial strategy.

#### 5. Leverage and Control

Real estate allows investors to use leverage — borrowing money to finance a purchase while using the property itself as collateral. This means you can control a large asset with relatively little of your own money upfront. Additionally, unlike stocks, real estate investors have more control over their investment. You can renovate, manage tenants, or even improve the property value, directly impacting your returns.

#### 6. Hedge Against Inflation

Real estate is often seen as a hedge against inflation. As the cost of living rises, so does the value of property and rent prices, making real estate a safe investment that often keeps pace with, or outpaces, inflation. This makes it an attractive option during times of economic uncertainty.

#### 7. Diversification

Adding real estate to your investment portfolio helps diversify your assets. It behaves differently than stocks and bonds, which means it can provide stability when the stock market is volatile. By spreading your investments across different asset classes, you reduce the risk of your entire portfolio being affected by one market’s performance.

###### In conclusion, real estate offers a combination of steady cash flow, long-term appreciation, tax advantages, and the ability to leverage your investment, all while providing a tangible asset. Whether you're investing in a home, a rental property, or a commercial space, real estate can be a great way to build wealth and secure your financial future.
author: Martin Doks

title: HOW TO BUY A HOUSE IN LAGOS: STEP-BY- STEP GUIDE FOR FIRST-TIME HOME BUYERS 2026 EDITION

content:
Buying a house in Lagos is one of the biggest financial decisions you will ever make and for first-time home buyers, the process can feel overwhelming. With rising property prices, complex documentation, and the fear of falling into the hands of fraudulent sellers, understanding the right
steps is crucial.

This guide breaks down a simple, clear, and professional step-by-step process to help you buy your first home in Lagos without stress.

Step-by-Step Guide to Buying a House in Lagos

Step 1: Determine Your Budget
Before you start viewing houses, you must know how much you can truly afford.

Consider:

- Cost of the house
- Legal fees (usually 5–10%)
- Agency fee (5% depending on property)
- Documentation fee (varies by location)
- Renovation or finishing costs

Tip: Lagos properties vary by area; Ikoyi, Lekki, and Victoria Island are premium markets, while Ajah, Sangotedo, and Ikorodu offer more affordable options.

Step 2: Identify Your Preferred Location
Location determines price, lifestyle, and long-term value.

Popular Buyer-Friendly Areas:

- Mainland: Yaba, Surulere, Ogudu, Gbagada
- Island: Lekki Phase 2, Ajah, Sangotedo, Ibeju-Lekki
- Premium: Ikoyi, Banana Island, Lekki Phase 1

Consider:

- Security
- Proximity to work/schools
- Road network
- Flooding history
- Future development potential

Step 3: Work With a Verified Real Estate Agent or Realtor
The Lagos property market is dynamic and, unfortunately, full of fraudulent listings.

A professional realtor helps you:

- Verify property documents
- Conduct due diligence
- Negotiate prices
- Avoid scams
- Get access to legitimate listings
- Understand market pricing

Avoid dealing directly with random online vendors or unverified agents.

Step 4: Start Viewing Properties
Once you’ve defined your budget and location, begin property inspections.

What to check during inspection:

- Quality of construction
- Structural integrity
- Water supply
- Electrical works
- Drainage system
- Surrounding environment
- Accessibility

If available, go with a building engineer to ensure the property is structurally sound.

Step 5: Conduct Document Verification
This is the most important part of buying a house in Lagos.

Key documents to verify include:

- C of O (Certificate of Occupancy)
- Governor’s Consent
- Deed of Assignment
- Survey Plan
- Approved Building Plan
- Tax Clearance (for some properties)

Verification should be done at:

- Lagos State Lands Bureau
- Surveyor-General’s Office
- Relevant Local Government offices

Never skip verification - It protects you from buying land under government acquisition or disputed property.

Step 6: Make an Offer and Negotiate
Your agent will help you negotiate the best deal.

Negotiations may include:

- Purchase price
- Payment plan
- Closing period
- Requests for minor repairs

Lagos is a competitive market. If the property is good and well-priced, move quickly.

Step 7: Draft and Sign the Sales Agreement

Once the price is agreed upon, the seller’s lawyer and your lawyer will draft a Sales Agreement or Deed of Assignment.

This legal document states:

- Buyer and seller details
- Property description
- Agreed price
- Payment structure
- Transfer terms

You should always have your own lawyer review the agreement.

Step 8: Make Payment (Securely)

Ensure all payments are made through:
- Bank transfer
- Escrow service (if available)
- Lawyer’s client account

Never pay in cash.
Always request official receipts and acknowledgement letters.

Step 9: Register Your Documents

After purchase, proceed with:

- Title registration
- Stamp duties
- Tax payments(if required)
- Governor’s Consent application(important in Lagos)

This protects your ownership and prevents disputes in the future.

Step 10: Take Possession of Your New Home

After completion of all paperwork:

- Collect all keys
- Collect copies of all approved documents
- Inspect the property again
- Take possession officially

Congratulations — you’re now a Lagos homeowner!


Common Mistakes First-Time Buyers Make and How to Avoid Them

❌ Not verifying documents

✔ Always cross-check at government offices.

❌ Rushing the buying process

✔ Take time to inspect and compare options.

❌ Dealing with quacks

✔ Work with verified realtors and legal professionals.

❌ Not budgeting for extra costs

✔ Add 10–15% to your budget for fees.

❌ Ignoring the environment

✔ Check for flooding, noise levels, and security.

Buying a home in Lagos doesn’t have to be stressful. With the right information, a professional realtor, and proper due diligence, you can make a safe and profitable investment.

If you’re a first-time home buyer, follow this step-by-step guide and work with trusted professionals. Your dream home in Lagos is within reach.

title: Ikoyi vs Lekki vs Ajah: Which Neighbourhood Is Best for Your Budget? — A Realtor’s Data-Driven Guide
excerpt: Choosing where to buy property on the Lagos Island axis, whether Ikoyi, Lekki, or Ajah goes beyond preference. In 2025, the Lagos real estate market has expe...
content:
Choosing where to buy property on the Lagos Island axis, whether Ikoyi, Lekki, or Ajah goes beyond preference. In 2025, the Lagos real estate market has experienced significant price adjustments driven by inflation, infrastructure expansion, developer activity and sustained demand.

Using verified 2025 pricing insights from PropertyPro, PrivateProperty, Nigeria Property Centre and market-wide valuation benchmarks, this guide breaks down the facts so you can make a smart, budget-aligned decision.

2025 Price Overview — Ikoyi vs Lekki vs Ajah

 1. Ikoyi — Premium Market, Elite Pricing

2025 data from Nigeria Property Centre places the average price of houses in Ikoyi at approximately ₦1.62 billion, with luxury homes stretching far higher.

Complementary market studies show residential property averaging about ₦980,000 per m², and a typical two-bed apartment starts from ₦ 250 million plus.

What this means:

Ikoyi is Lagos’ unchallenged luxury market. Prices reflect limited supply, exclusivity, high security, and proximity to major business districts. For investors, Ikoyi offers capital preservation and long-term appreciation, though entry costs are extremely high.

Ideal For

- High-net-worth individuals
- Executives & expatriates
- Buyers seeking luxury, security & status
- Long-term wealth preservation investors



 2. Lekki; Mid-to-Upper Market with Balanced Value

Lekki remains one of the most dynamic markets in Lagos due to its infrastructure, lifestyle appeal, and strong rental demand.

In 2025:

- Average price for houses on PropertyPro is approximately ₦111.78 million
- Market data shows ₦615,000 per m² for residential land in Lekki Phase 1
- Typical 3-4 bedroom duplexes now sell for ₦ 350 million and above
- Premium or newly built homes range ₦500-900 million depending on finishing & estate quality

 What This Means:

Lekki strikes the perfect middle ground, affordable, compared to Ikoyi but with modern estates, malls, top schools, and proximity to commercial hubs. It is also one of the most liquid markets, good if you plan to resell or rent.

Ideal For:

- Middle-to-upper income earners
- Young families
- Corporate professionals
- Rental income investors
- Buyers prioritizing amenities & convenience



3. Ajah; Most Affordable Island-Axis Market with Growth Potential

Ajah continues to attract buyers looking for value and affordability.

2025 data shows:

- Average cost of residential land is ₦470,000 per m²
- A typical 4 bedroom duplex averages about ₦ 200 million
- Plots in areas like Sangotedo, Abraham Adesanya and Badore sell between ₦30-100 million (depending on title & estate development stage)

 What This Means: 

Ajah provides the lowest entry point for Lagos Island property. Development is expanding rapidly along the Lekki–Epe Expressway, making Ajah one of the best long-term appreciation zones for budget buyers or investors. However, infrastructure varies by location, so due diligence is essential.

Ideal For:

- First-time buyers
- Budget-conscious families
- Early-stage investors
- Buyers seeking long-term price appreciation
- Plot/estate development investors


Why Prices Have Shifted in 2025

Across PropertyPro, PrivateProperty and Nigeria Property Centre data, several patterns show up:

1. Demand for mid-market estates continues rising:
Lekki and Ajah are absorbing middle-income demand because Ikoyi and Banana Island have priced out many buyers.

2. Inflation & construction costs have pushed prices upward:
Materials, labour, and land documentation costs have all increased, impacting final market prices.

3. Luxury zones continue to appreciate steadily:
Ikoyi and prime Lekki zones remain popular among high-net-worth buyers, diaspora investors, and corporate renters.

4. Infrastructure drives value:
Road upgrades, drainage improvements, and private estate development are increasing land values in Lekki and Ajah.

 
Which Neighborhood Is Best for Your Budget? (2025)

Below is a simple decision guide based on your budget and long-term goals.

Choose Ikoyi if you want:

- Luxury living
- High security & exclusivity
- Long-term capital preservation
- Proximity to elite schools & diplomatic zones
- A premium neighborhood with stable value

Budget starting point:₦250 million for apartments; ₦1billion plus for houses


 Choose Lekki if you want:

- A balance of lifestyle, price & convenience
- Good neighborhood amenities
- Strong rental income potential
- A vibrant environment for families and professionals
- Better liquidity if you plan to resell

Budget starting point:₦350 to ₦900 million for duplexes


 Choose Ajah if you want:

- Entry-level affordability
- High growth potential
- Larger land sizes for lower prices
- Many new estates to choose from
- An opportunity to get in early before values spike

Budget starting point:₦30 to ₦80 million for plots; approximately ₦200 million for duplexes.


Realtor’s Final Recommendation (2025)

If your goal is:

- Prestige & luxury → Choose Ikoyi
- Balanced value & lifestyle comfort → Choose Lekki
- Affordability & long-term growth → Choose Ajah

As a realtor, my strongest recommendation for most buyers in 2025 is Lekki, especially Lekki Phase 1 & its organized estates. It offers the most balanced combination of price, infrastructure, rental demand and long-term value.

However, if you are a first-time buyer or investor with a moderate budget, Ajah is the smartest entry point.
